By ED MORSE
The second annual studentfaculty camp was held in an atmosphere of healthy seclusion at
The Rocks, Maryland where 57
members of the Hopkins community met to study informally
the problems of student life,
student government and studentfaculty relations.
The camp, which was a success if only because its atmosphere of informality removed
normal communication barriers
found among the various parts
of the University, established
one of the rare opportunities to
see the total University concept
that our presidents from Dr.
Gilman to Dr. Eisenhower have
tried to instill here.
The encampment was broken
into four discussion groups as
follows: The Judicial System
(academic and non-academic),
Student Government structure,
Student Government and extra
curricular activities and the
Academic Community, led by
Fred Bergerson, Neal Grove,

After opening remarks by Bob

Elder, Chairman of the camp,

group of faculty, students and
administrators. He noted that
the camp was held to air out
problems from all sides of the
University, not specificially to
find workable solutions, but to
gain understanding of problems
which each department of the
University confronts.
The Judicial Problems brought
up indicated a desire to have a
judicial body on campus to regulate non academic aspects of
the Gentleman's Code. This is to
eliminate muddle resulting from

the Homewood's multitude of organizations attempting to control violations in restricted areas

with little effective coordination
powers on campus. It was suggested that organized campus
political parties running candidates for undergraduate offices
could effectively give more interest to Student Government.
Also, if the SC were an instrument of formal feedback from
students to faculty, its prestige
and importance would increase.

judiciary responsibilities of the
D.S.R.C. be removed to a separate group so that the D.S.R.C.

scheduling of events. It was

discrimination.

The Johns Hopkins University
announced this summer that it
has changed the name of its
School of Engineering to School
of Engineering Science.
"The new name implies no
new curriculum," Dean Roy said.
"Actually we have been following
a different approach to engineering education tor more than ten
years and this change now merely makes the name more meaningful."
In 1950 Hopkins shifted from
the traditional, pragmatic approach to one in favor of more
emphasis upon basic science,
more attention to the humanities
and social sciences, and greater
freedom for each student in the
selection of his course. Similar
changes have been made during
recent years in other engineering
schools and colleges throughout
the country.
"Engineers have always been
concerned with the design of
machines and systems," Dean
Roy said, "and this has always
required the exercise of judgment as well as knowledge of
science. Engineers are still concerned with design and there is
still an _art of engineering, but
modern technology has grown so

complex that there is much less
room for the exercise of judgment and much greater demand
for knowledge and application of
science and mathematics.
"The safety factor that is
satisfactory in the design of a

steel frame for a building will
not do for the structure of a
high speed aircraft, if the plane
is to fly. Alloys that endure in a
steam engine would not stand up
against the temperature inside
a rocket engine.

The Johns Hopkins University
announced this summer that it
has changed the name of its
School of Engineering to School
of Engineering Science.
"The new name implies no
new curriculum," Dean Roy said.
"Actually we have been following
a different approach to engineering education tor more than ten
years and this change now merely makes the name more meaningful."
In 1950 Hopkins shifted from
the traditional, pragmatic approach to one in favor of more
emphasis upon basic science,
more attention to the humanities
and social sciences, and greater
freedom for each student in the
selection of his course. Similar
changes have been made during
recent years in other engineering
schools and colleges throughout
the country.
"Engineers have always been
concerned with the design of
machines and systems," Dean
Roy said, "and this has always
required the exercise of judgment as well as knowledge of
science. Engineers are still concerned with design and there is
still an _art of engineering, but
modern technology has grown so

complex that there is much less
room for the exercise of judgment and much greater demand
for knowledge and application of
science and mathematics.
"The safety factor that is
satisfactory in the design of a

steel frame for a building will
not do for the structure of a
high speed aircraft, if the plane
is to fly. Alloys that endure in a
steam engine would not stand up
against the temperature inside
a rocket engine.
